Biodegradable materials: If all plastic disappeared, we would have to rely on biodegradable materials such as bamboo, hemp, and cornstarch-based plastics. These materials are sustainable, renewable, and can decompose naturally without harming the environment.
Metal and glass: We could also use metal and glass containers as alternatives to plastic. These materials are durable, reusable, and can be recycled easily.

Natural fibers: Natural fibers such as cotton, linen, and jute can also be used as alternatives to plastic. These materials are biodegradable, renewable, and can be woven into various forms such as bags, baskets, and clothing.

3D printing: With the advancement of 3D printing technology, we can create customized and durable plastic-free objects using materials such as PLA (polylactic acid) and ABS (acrylonitrile butadiene styrene).

Upcycling: We can also upcycle existing materials such as old furniture, clothing, and electronics to create new and functional objects. This approach not only reduces waste but also promotes creativity and resourcefulness.
